tn.text: Paul contrasts human wisdom and God's wisdom. He emphasizes that spiritual wisdom comes from God.
Here this means fellow Christians, including both men and women.

tn.ref: I decided to know nothing ... except Jesus Christ
tn.text: Paul spoke about the crucifixion of Christ rather than human ideas. AT: "I decided to talk as much as I could ... about Jesus Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
"I was visiting with you"
Possible meanings are: 1) "physically weak" (UDB) or 2) "feeling like I could not do what I needed to do."
words that sound wise and with which the speaker hopes to cause people to do or believe something
Paul interrupts his main argument to explain what he means by "wisdom" and to whom he desires to speak.
The word "Now" is used here to mark a break in the main teaching. Paul begins to explain that true wisdom is God's wisdom.
"speak words of wisdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"mature believers"
"before God created anything"
"in order to ensure our future glory"
"Jesus, the glorious Lord"

tn.ref: Things that no eye ... imagined, the things ... who love him
tn.text: This is an incomplete sentence. Some translations make it a complete sentence: "Things that no eye ... imagined; these are the things ... who love him." Others leave it incomplete but show that it is incomplete by using non-final punctuation here and beginning the next verse as a continuation of this verse: "'Things that no eye ... imagined, the things ... who love him'—"

tn.ref: Things that no eye has seen, no ear has heard, no mind has imagined
tn.text: This is a triplet referring to all parts of a person to emphasize that no man has ever been aware of the things that God has prepared. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the things that God has prepared for those who love him
tn.text: The Lord has created in heaven wonderful surprises for those who love him.
Paul speaks of the truths about Jesus and the cross. If [[:en:bible:notes:1co:02:08|2:9]] is treated as an incomplete sentence, "these are the things."

tn.ref: For who knows a person's thoughts except the spirit of the person in him?
tn.text: Paul uses this question to emphasize that no one knows what a person is thinking except the person himself. AT: "No one knows what a person is thinking except that person's spirit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This refers to a person's inner being, his own spiritual nature.

tn.ref: no one knows the deep things of God except the Spirit of God
tn.text: "only the Spirit of God knows the deep things of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
Here the word "we" includes both Paul and his audience. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: freely given to us by God
tn.text: "that God freely gave to us" or "that God has freely given us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: The Spirit interprets spiritual words with spiritual wisdom
tn.text: The Holy Spirit communicates God's truth to believers in the Spirit's own words and gives them his own wisdom.
"explains"
Here the word "we" includes both Paul and his audience. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
the non-Christian person, who has not received the Holy Spirit
"because understanding these things requires the aid of the Spirit"
"The believer who has received the Spirit"

tn.ref: For who can know the mind of the Lord, that he can instruct him?
tn.text: Paul uses this question to emphasize that no one knows the mind of the Lord. AT: "No one can know the mind of the Lord, so no one can teach him anything he does not already know" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
